title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific conditions. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, including Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program. Programs operated by Indian tribal organizations are covered under SEC. 479B. The part applies to Indian tribes running programs similar to states, with modifications for plan requirements like identifying service areas and approving foster homes based on tribal standards for child safety. The part ensures the safety and accountability of children in foster care by determining the federal share based on an Indian tribe's per capita income and other relevant information submitted to the Secretary. An Indian tribe can provide relevant information to the Secretary for calculating their per capita income. The Secretary will consider this information before making the calculation. The Secretary will determine the proportions to be paid to Indian tribes, ensuring they receive no less than the corresponding amount specified for a State. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments. An Indian tribe may use Federal or State funds to match payments for which they are eligible under section 474. The Secretary can modify requirements under this part if it benefits the safety of children served by the tribe. Participating Indian tribes in a consortium can submit a single plan that meets the section 471 requirements. An Indian tribe or intertribal consortium and a State can form a cooperative agreement for fund administration under section 471. The agreement must incorporate the provisions of this section and can be modified or revoked by either party. The Secretary must establish regulations within a year of enactment in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The Secretary will promulgate regulations in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations to carry out this section. The definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are as defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The amendments made by this section take effect on the date of enactment of this Act.
